item.title: Dune: Overhyped or Underappreciated?
item.author: deadfast@proton.io (deadfast)
item.description:
Finally got around to reading Dune by Frank Herbert after Harrison kept recommending it. My honest take? It’s… complicated.

The Good

The first book is genuinely good. Herbert created this incredibly detailed universe with complex politics, ecology, and mysticism all woven together. The world-building is impressive, and you can see why it’s considered a sci-fi classic.

The movie (at least the first one) was visually stunning and did justice to the source material. Denis Villeneuve really understood the assignment.

item.title: The Three-Body Problem: Hard Sci-Fi That Hits Different
item.author: deadfast@proton.io (deadfast)
item.description:
The Three-Body Problem by Cixin Liu is the kind of sci-fi that makes you question everything about humanity’s place in the universe. Rating: 8.1/10 (yeah, a lot of my sci-fi reads end up around there).

What Makes It Special

This isn’t your typical Western sci-fi. Liu brings a distinctly Chinese perspective to concepts like fate vs. free will, and it’s refreshing. The book feels less about individual heroism and more about humanity as a whole facing an existential threat.
